page.title: 06JOBS ON HALL FARM.
page.content: We went to Hall Farm and Robert Claydon, the farmer told us about the year on the farm. They start in September, getting the ground ready for the next year, drilling the ground with seeds. They also start lifting sugar beet. There are 350 acres of sugar beet. With machines they can lift no more than 10 acres of beet a day, so it takes until December. Lorries come every day to collect it, and before collecting, the mud is shaken off. January and February are the main times for maintenance. In March, the farmer sprays the barley and in May, the beet is sprayed, otherwise the weeds get thick and the crops die. In June hay is made. Towards the end of July harvesting starts. They get the combine out and cut down corn. By the end of August the jobs are done.
